review_title: Didn't expect it to be this bad
review_detailed_main:
The endless sponsor banners that consumed the first two minutes of the movie should have told me everything I needed to know about this flick.

Horrible writing in a corny attempt to have as many unnecessary fight scenes as possible... Save yourself the aggravation and watch something else

I'm sorry, but there is no excuse for such a film. I enjoyed the romping first film. It was like the best type of buddy film. Expendables but with only the Sly-Arnie bromance.

But this?

Firstly, what genre does it actually think it is? Gritty espionage movie, contemporary high tech thriller, sci-fi, Kung Fu? It undermines your perceptions at every opportunity. Actually,, what decade is it supposed to be? With its contemporary 2018 setting soon becoming a garish abundance of neon, and a plinky plonky 80's electronic soundtrack.

Yes, there's a bit of an 1980's revival since the wonderful 80's themed Strange Days, but to me, instead of accomplishing that feeling of being returned to those wondrous days of youth, it's was more like being dragged back to my parents first divorce. What about the plot I hear you cry? The plot holes make Swiss cheese look like that big lump of mature cheddar that has sat at the back of the fridge since before you can remember, but you don't have the heart to throw out. It's like a cacophony of familiar household noises. The ones that wake you up in the middle of the night with the feeling that you are either being burgled by a rhino, or the dogs going through the bins. I would love to read the script, to see what the writer's original idea was, and if it started off as a good idea and was then put through the studio's equivalent of Banksy's Girl with Balloon. All in all, I came away feeling like I do increasingly with films these days. Depressed and short of pocket.

review_title: Greatest cinematic masterpiece since Schindler's List and Orson Welles!!
review_detailed_main:
Sylvester Stallone, Dave Bautista, Xiaoming Huang, Jesse Metcalfe, 50 Cent, Wes Chatham and Chen Tang. What else can one ask for?

Ladies and gentleman, we are talking Sylvester "Sly" Stallone, an ICON of action movies who, many newcomers movie goers wouldn't know, starred in Rambo, Rocky I-IV and The Specialist along Sharon Stone.

Then we have Dave Bautista - brawn meets intellect- where an alpha male the size of Koko the Gorilla solves Rubik's Cube faster than Will Smith's character in Pursuit of Happyness.

50 cent stars as a 'sly' ... (get it?) higher-tier consultant or something of the firm and is relatively restrained for all his chutzpah and Crack-A-Bottle soundtrack.

The movie portrays, projects and extrapolates what it would be like in futuristic prison. Gone are the days of Salinas County Jail and what not. We have AI-driven, robotics who take care of an entire engine that is called Hades (underground.. see your Greek Mythology).

I was a big fan of Stallone in the first Escape Plan where he wrote a dissertation about the structural engineering of the prison and the same intellect, level-headedness, coolness and wit (such as Go scene) is present in the sequel.

Each shots are cinematographic masterpiece and not your typical Instagram filters. Sure critics will say the delivery is wooden, or complaint of the ropey dialogue or abrumpt jumping of scenes or lack of storylines and numerous other plotholes... but the end the of the day this is not your average Fast and The Furious meets Prison Break meets Tolstoy's War and Piece.

In fact, some of the robotics scene alone is worth the movie entrance and budget of many Hollywood films. Only Hollywood can provide insight and glimpse into superior graphics, visualization and VFX as to what a futuristic prison will look like with hi-tech gadgets.

Bravo. Well done folks. Take a bow. It may not be an Oscar material but sure HP Lovecraft, Jules Verse and even Robert Heinlein and Asimov (as in conjoined Robert Heinlein and Asimov in an alterante universe) could have foreshadow'd such master piece.

With all aplogies to Shakespeare:

If Escape Plan Franchise is the.food of love, play on!!

Play on!

review_detailed_main: I can't believe that Stallone has done this movie, Cinematography is extremely poor, Main asian characters can't speak English properly, Visual Effects poor, Dialogues poor. everything about this movie is below average.

Any action movie fan is probably familiar with this film's hilariously bad reputation. People just hate it. With a passion. And it's hilarious.

Yes, ok, yes. It's bad. Cheap-looking, cheaply executed entertainment with meh acting and an overwrought story that can't just pick a lane genre-wise. It's an action thriller, with a bit of a sci-fi element that doesn't really work (the prison is futuristic and high tech), making it look like a Doctor Who (2005) episode.

It may be the worst of Sylvester Stallone's career, which is sad because he still has charisma and physicality. I love Dave Bautista, and was excited to see him and Stallone doing their thing together, even if Arnold's absence is still damaging to the movie's appeal. Sadly, Bautista is barely in it. He is in like, three or four scenes total, and he only has two action scenes, in which all he really does is shoot some dudes. Sylvester Stallone strangely isn't in it as much as he should be, though I guess he's there a fair amount. But when he gets top-billing, he should appear way more than a fair amount. It's horribly underwhelming.

The action sequences are the movie's saving grace, and that's not saying much. There are some well-choreographed fight scenes, a cool bar shootout where Stallone and Bautista kill bad guys, and some good sequences at the end. Sly does have a brutal final fight, which is cool. The violence is pretty graphic, but not OTT.

Xiaoming Huan is a great martial artist tho. He takes center stage for much of the movie with lots of cool kung fu-oriented fight scenes. My problem isn't that he's so central, it's that he's central at the expense of Stallone and Bautista. It's like when you're at a concert for a band you love, and you really like the opener band, but then you realize they have the majority of the concert's length. No matter how good they are, they're not who you're there for.

It's just kind of a mess. The script is muddled, the action is well-done but kind of underwhelming, the two great leads are barely present, and the villains are completely forgettable. It might be really hard to like for a lot of people, and this is as forgiving a review as I can give. It's definitely not the worst movie I've ever seen, like it seems to be with so many other people. It's still better than the DTV garbage Steven Seagal is still putting out.

Well, in my old years Sylvester Stallone was my second favorite actor (I'm sorry, but this is true). First, of course, was Schwarzenegger. Yes, good old days (hmmmm... I'm only 29! What is old days!?)

From Stallone you expect always one thing - action, action and action! And a little drama (remember Rocky?). Yes, he can this. But in my heart he always a fearless hero. Besides, I liked another his characters in comedy.

But, Escape Plan. The first movie was good. Not excellent, but you have this "warm" feelings after film. For me, there are three basis of success: good actors, good story and good atmosphere. And Escape Plan partly has everything. Good actors - well, there are "stars of 90th" Stallone and Schwarzenegger. Good story - well, neither new, nor very interesting, but with some charm. Good atmosphere - yes for me.

And from second part I expected two things - Stallone and good atmosphere. And... got nothing.

The story is very similar to old Plan with some modification. In the centre of plot two Asian brothers, one of which work for Stallone's company. But there no interest for looking at all acting. The actors are washy and their characters are similar.

Two pillars of movie - Stallone himself and Bautista, hadn't time and willing to show themself in full force. Sly has a little time maybe of his age. Well, but I turn on this movie because of him! And Bautista... Well, Bautista is Bautista. He is weak as actor and you can use him as one-time characters, such as: "This is Bautista! Wow!". And then forgot about him. His best role is in the Guardians of the Galaxy as Drax the Destroyer. This is mean something, if you understand me.

The overall atmosphere is weird. Creators thought about future prison as collection of dark with color lights, robots and holograms. But this is more hiding bad fantasy, then showing "future".

The movie is so "peaceful", that showing only minimum of the minimums of blood. You know, this "piu-piu" sound and etc. But in the last scene we can look at the beaten face of Sly.

Main villain - are your joking?! He is so cute and useless, that you can't perceive him seriously. Sorry, pal. Even plot twist (if we can call it such word) can't help.

I expected for trap, but not so big! Sorry Sly, but we can't eat this.

Only 2 Sly from 10.

review_detailed_main: Thank god I mange to escape from this bad movie after half hour

It used to be that Stallone mumbled his lines and was unintelligible. These days he seems to be in movies where everyone else mumbles their lines and are unintelligible!

A movie with no plot, stand-alone scenes that don't fit together, and contrivances galore so that the writers didn't have to think too hard about getting the characters out of an inescapable prison.

Two questions (not worth answering):

1) what was the laser device all about? It was never used.

2) Where did all the prisoners go in the end? Did they evaporate?

Truly awful. Don't waste your time.

Some Chechnyan terrorists are about the execute some hostages. Among the terrorists is also a Westerner who is tasked with the execution. But then he turns against the terrorists and helps the hostages escape. He also takes the time to destroy their weapons cache, which delays their escape and as a result one of the hostages ends up shot.

Back in the US we learn this was an operation run by Breslin (Stallone) who ends up firing the one guy responsible for the delay the in the escape. This guy, Kimbral, was trying to modernize Breslin's operation with algorithms and according to one such algorithm they should have all made it out in time alive even with the destruction of the weapons.

Years later, one of Breslin's team members, Shu, is tasked with protecting his brilliant tech-guru cousin. There is an attack and both end up taken prisoners in some high tech prison called HADES. The prison us run by no other than Kimbral but his investors want the technology that Shu's cousin developed so they're torturing him to the get the info. Kimbral developed the prison precisely so that not even Breslin could escape. Meanwhile another guy from the the team is captured and in HADES. So Breslin and 3 or 4 left on his team will have to figured out who to get their friends out, while those one the inside will have to figure out how to escape from a prison with no clear layout with the help of some other convicts. Eventually Breslin himself gets himself imprisoned to get the others out.

Not sure Escape Plan ever needed a sequel but it certainly didn't need a C-movie sequel. For the first 20 minutes or so EP2 actually works that is until HADES is introduced. In HADES everything is obnoxiously dark except for some 80s special effects occasionally. It is probably the lamest movie-prison ever shown. How they paid whoever claimed to be a set-designer I don't know. But like all Chinese-coprodutions, this movie doesn't exactly aim for quality and excellence. There are some cool martial-arts scenes but then other action scenes are weak. The only cool thing are some robots since this is an automated AI-run prison. Bautista is in this movie, not kicking butt. Curtis Jackson not sure what his role is here. Escape Plan 2 offers little to the audience.

review_title: Horrible and a wasted sequel that is nowhere as good as the first movie.
review_detailed_main:
Escape Plan 2: Hades (1 out of 5 stars).

Escape Plan 2 is just pure horrible and nothing can describe why Sylvester Stallone would agree to being in this sequel. The first film was at least decent with him and Arnold Schwarzenegger costarring together and being in a movie were they have to work together to break out a maximum-security prison. However, this sequel fails to live up to the first movie. For starters, this film is a straight to dvd type of movie. You can expect it to be low quality this time. Sylvester Stallone is barely in this movie as well.

The plot is lame and dumb. It focuses on Shu Ren (Huang Xiaoming) who works for Breslin's security company and gets captured. And placed in a futuristic prison. Were the owner of the place is known as the zookeeper. And rewards the prisoners if they survive the fights. They have a robotic droid that is a medic in med bay. They have a hologram cell of your preferred setting. Shu is captured cause the owner of the prison wants something from Ren. That involves satellites. While Ray (Sylvester Stallone) and his team Abigail (Jaime King), Hush (Curtis Jackson), and newcomer Luke (Jesse Metcalfe) are trying to get in and to break out with Ren. The plot was all over the place. From the beginning scene was a failed mission of a break out. And a twist that is not as exciting. It was just bad.

The direction was horrible. The shootouts were terribly executed. Come on, guys are shooting at each other up front and the bullets are not hitting anyone or anything. It is like they are shooting blanks towards each other. The fight scenes are consisting of close up camera shots and quick editing cuts which does not help make it exciting.

Stallone should have passed on this sequel. Dave Bautista was a waste in this role. Appearing for a small amount of screen time. Huang Xiaoming gave a dull performance.

Overall, Escape Plan 2: Hades is just pure terrible. A stupid plot. The concept is overkilled with a futuristic prison that has holograms, a rotating prison that changes its layouts, a robotic medic, and force field doors. Yes, it is ridiculous. The action and shootouts are badly executed. And sadly, it does have an ending that leaves for another sequel.
This is a disaster. Not even a "prety female no brain" characeter. Dont waste your time - students with phones shoot better movies than this!

While 2013's Escape Plan was no masterpiece, it did tap into the dumb-fun action movie vibe of the two leads' heyday. The film was a simple and entertaining enough B-grade actioner with Sylvester Stallone and Arnold Schwarzenegger making a good team.

Although it's likely that most missed it, 2018 saw the release of sequel Escape Plan 2: Hades starring Sylvester Stallone and Dave Bautista. The film went straight to DVD in the US and yet, despite it being a flop overall, a third installment is still currently in the works. The plot sees some of Ray Breslin's (Stallone) new recruits get kidnapped and thrown into Hades, a maximum security prison not unlike The Tomb from the last movie except it's always moving and shifting, making its layout hard to figure out, and some of the staff are actual robots.

Yes. Robots.

Breslin attempts, with the help of his hacker friend Hush (50 Cent), former associate Trent (Dave Bautista) and others, to break his team out of Hades while Breslin's protégé Shu Ren (Huang Xiaoming), one of the prisoners, tries to understand the prison's inner workings. Eventually, everyone finds themselves in Hades and the real "escape plan" is finally put into motion.

Escape Plan's premise should have been an easy one to bank on in continuing sequels. Essentially, you could have just had Breslin tackle different types of prisons with the help of Schwarzenegger or other big name co-stars with a new hammy, villainous warden every time. Somehow, however, Hades is a convoluted mess and neither Stallone or Bautista get much screen time. Both really come into play in the film's last third and, until that point, we're mostly spending time with Shu Ren and other new, far less charismatic and entertaining leads.

This movie feels more like the fourth or fifth movie in a tired franchise than it does a straight-up sequel. The plot never really takes off, the new characters are dull, the writing is terrible, the twists are uninspired and the film ends abruptly, without any real ending. While Bautista, when he's actually in the movie, is likable, the cinematography is at least competent and the prison's concept is appealing, this is all frankly half-assed.

What could have been a light-hearted and fun sequel turns out to be a surprisingly miserable experience that should alienate both newcomers and fans of the original. In the same way that The Expendables ran out of steam with its third film, this one completely deflates after just one movie.

review_detailed_main: I actually liked the first movie, so I'm very disappointed in this sequel. The camerawork is terrible, plot jumps all over the place, acting is mediocre, storyline non existent, music badly placed and too bombastic and the CGI is worse than the Scorpion King.... To make matters worse it's not even about escaping a prison anymore and the way they eventually do it is unrealistic (people getting information without problems while this information is supposed to be unfindable, passing notes and building things in a prison where they are being watched 24/7 by a computer,...) Just a way of time and not even worth to be played as a background movie on a party.

I watched 1st part recently, liked it so much hence got to watch 2nd installment but i should say that i got dissappointed since they seem to have complicated with so much confusing tech, the screenplay could've been a lot better. I just got headache by watching it. Stallone was totally wasted in this one.

I have no idea what Stallone was thinking making this awful movie. I will try to be fair and try to watch it one more time but that movie makes no sense to me, looks disjoint and chaotic in story line. Sylvester Stallone does not seem to be main character and instead you have lots of Chinese stuff (a give away in the movie production). You definitely see a clash between the western and Chinese clash in the movie style.
Part 1 was fantasic.. part 2 is the opposit. Silvester is a Legend. Stop acting like Rocky, you will nail comedy, family or mastermids movies
Terrible movie i got headache watching this. Actors was fine, but i think the cameramen and editors need to double check the movie.

We know our movies pander to us, and we know the plots and acting are trash, but we enjoy our trash and will continue to watch whatever they keep pumping out.

We don't feel the need to whine and cry that people see through the obvious manipulation, we don't care people won't come to see this in theaters or pay money to stream it.

We know who the characters are that we watch and what the actors stand for, and we don't hide behind insults and victimhood from the messages portrayed.

If you don't like it, fine. If you are uncomfortable, ok.

Don't watch it. Don't bother us.

That's the difference.

review_title: Could have been so much more.
review_detailed_main:
The foundation for a good and interesting story was here, but with the numerous plotholes, bad acting, shotty music, and many assumptions built that you watched the first one like Marvel's long line of films, I didn't care.

My overall emotion is that I feel bad for what little this film gave yet what more it could provide. I did get one chuckle out of Dave Bautista because Dave Bautista.
What a load of rubbish. The first Escape Plan was an enjoyable film, this one is very poor and I dread to think what the 3rd instalment is going to be like. Don't waste your time on this.

review_title: Lots of Action but Nothing Happens
review_detailed_main:
Must be one of the first films I have "seen" were literally nothing is happening. Even during the action sequences.

Camera action is your basic point and shoot. The film seems to have been filmed entirely in close-up. Sets are minimal and unimaginative. Most of the actors are bland and forgettable. It got so uninteresting I actually picked up book of poetry I bought about 15 years ago that I've been meaning to read.

review_title: Awful sequel to a good movie
review_detailed_main: I enjoyed the first one a lot. I actually watched it twice. It was tense with interesting puzzles and action scenes. I just can't understand how they were able to mess this one so bad. The acting is awful for the most part, there is no flow to the scenes, they're entirely disconnected, and the story is terrible. I gave it 3 stars because in that terrible story there is a plot twist which actually caught me by surprise and one action scene that was half-decent. Beyond that not worth it.
